TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE . He is represented before the ORG by Ms K. ORG , a lawyer practising in GPE . The respondent Government are represented by their Agent , Mr PERSON , from ORG .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant lived in GPE , GPE from DATE onwards . He lived there with his wife and QUANTITY children , who are all NORP nationals . The children are attending school there .

CARDINAL . In DATE he was extradited from GPE to GPE for a criminal prosecution . On DATE ORG found the applicant guilty of attempted murder and sentenced him to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment . He is serving his prison sentence in FAC in GPE .

CARDINAL . The applicant has been trying to be transferred to a NORP prison so he can be closer to his family who , he states , are living in impoverished conditions and do not have means to travel to GPE . Also , his son ’s mental health has been damaged by his not being able to see his father .

CARDINAL . He sent several requests in that regard to ORG . On DATE , CARDINAL DATE and CARDINAL May and CARDINAL DATE the Ministry replied by letter , giving negative responses . It firstly reasoned that the applicant was a NORP national and thus it would not be possible to transfer him to GPE . In another letter , on DATE , the ORG reasoned that NORP law allowed such a transfer only exceptionally and that the fact that the applicant ’s family was living in GPE was not such an exceptional circumstance .

CARDINAL . The applicant is in contact with his family by regular telephone calls , allowed for TIME once a week , and unrestricted written correspondence . The family has not been able to visit him yet , according to the applicant , mainly because of the distance , poor health and lack of funds .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the applicant applied for NORP nationality and simultaneous revocation of his NORP nationality . It seems that these proceedings are pending .
CARDINAL . The applicant approached various other bodies , including the ombudsman , the ORG and numerous non - governmental organisations , about his situation .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) , a constitutional appeal may be lodged by any natural or legal person who claims that a final decision given in proceedings to which he or she was a party , or a measure or any other action taken by a public authority , has infringed his or her fundamental rights or freedoms as guaranteed by a constitutional law .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that when ORG upholds a constitutional appeal it must either set aside the impugned decision by a public authority or , where the infringement of a right guaranteed by LAW is the result of an interference other than a decision , forbid the authority concerned to continue to infringe the right and order it to reestablish the status quo if that is possible .

CARDINAL . In a judgment no . III . ÚS CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE it defined an “ other action taken by a public authority ” in section DATE of the Act on ORG largely as a CARDINAL - off , illegal and unconstitutional attack by such an authority on constitutionally guaranteed fundamental rights ( freedoms ) that , at the time of the attack , posed a continuous threat to an existing legal situation , while such an attack itself was not an expression ( result ) of a decision - making power of the authority , and as such fell outside the usual review proceedings .

CARDINAL . NORP In a decision no . I. ÚS CARDINAL of DATE it held that a primary feature of “ other action taken by a public authority ” in section CARDINAL of LAW must be that the interference was still going on at the time of the decision of ORG .

CARDINAL . In its judgment no . III . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE it held that for admissibility of a constitutional appeal under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) it was immaterial how the challenged act of an administrative authority had been labelled . What mattered was only if the administrative authority had by that act interfered with an individual ’s legal standing in an authoritative and possibly final way . The substantive content of an act was always decisive , rather than its formal designation .

CARDINAL . In its judgment no . PERSON . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL of CARDINAL June CARDINAL it held that the ratified and promulgated international agreements on human rights and fundamental freedoms , including the Convention , were part of NORP constitutional law .
